brief.brief: To create processing statements to implement your Service Manager applications, use the accepted syntax.

detail.detail: Reserved Words have a specific meaning in Service Manager. You cannot use a reserved word for any other purpose or give it any other meaning.
Check the List of Reserved Words before you try to write a processing statement.
A literal is an explicit value.
A string is a sequence of zero or more numeric, alphabetic, or special characters enclosed with double quotation marks.
1. A string can be any combination of letters, digits, or special characters.
2. Enclose all strings in double quotation marks.
3. A string can be any length.
4. A string may include any special characters including those used as operators.
5. Put a backslash (\) in front of double quotes (") that is part of the string. This distinguishes them from double quotes at the beginning or end of a string.
For example, Vendor\"473 denotes the string: Vendor"473. (\ is the default escape key.)
6. Enter non-characters as two hexadecimal digits preceded by a backslash.
Enter numbers as an optional sign followed by digits optionally followed by a decimal point, more digits, optionally followed by the letter E and an exponent.
Time uses a 24-hour clock. '00:00:00' is midnight; '12:00:00' is noon; '18:00:00' is 6 p.m.
1. Enclose times in single quotation marks.
2. Time can be either relative or absolute.
3. Enter absolute time in the Format: 'mm/dd/yy hh:mm:ss'.
4. The use of hh:mm:ss is optional in absolute time. If omitted, hh:mm:ss defaults to 00:00:00.
5. Enter relative time in Format: 'ddd hh:mm:ss'.
6. The use of ddd is optional in relative time. If omitted, ddd defaults to 0.
7. The use of seconds (:ss) is optional in either relative or absolute time. If omitted, seconds default to 00.
8. To set a time variable to a 0 value, use $time='00:00'.
A Boolean indicates true, false, or of unknown truth-value.
1. Indicate the Boolean directly as true, false, or unknown.
2. Indicate the Boolean in either upper or lower case characters.
3. Yes is a synonym for true. No is a synonym for false.

A variable is a named entity that refers to data and to which you can assign values. The data type and value of a variable can be different at different times. A variable identifier can have a primitive or compound data type as its value.
1. A variable must begin with a dollar sign ($) and an alphabetic character followed by zero or more alphanumeric characters that may include periods but may not include blanks.
2. A variable name can be any length.
3. Service Manager determines the data type of a variable as the type associated with the value of the data assigned to it in an application.
4. Any variable may be set to a null value by assigning the value NULL into it.
Note: Service Manager treats all variables, except parameter variables, as global variables among all applications run within the process or task.
1. You can use a literal in any place you use a variable.
2. You can use any number of variables in an application.
3. You can use a variable in any field in an application panel except in the Application field and the Label field.
4. You can use a variable as a value in a processing statement.
